course_title: Advanced Studies in Music History and Musicology - ORAL/WRITTN TRAD

001.comments: ORAL AND WRITTEN TRADITIONS IN EARLY MUSICThis seminar will explore the music of Western Europe in the Middle Ages from the perspective of musical transmission: how music was composed, learned, taught, and disseminated in an age when music writing and printing was just beginning to emerge. Topics will include theories on the oral and written transmission of Gregorian chant, orality and literacy in secular song, pitch and rhythm in early polyphony, the format and function of music manuscripts, the role of notational innovations in composition, and the ways in which the rise of music printing related to practical music-making. Through these perspectives a wide variety of Medieval and Renaissance musical repertory will be explored in depth. Students taking this seminar will give regular in-class presentations based on reading/liste and ~ning assignments and will be expected to complete a research project culminating in a paper and final oral presentation.Prerequisite:  MUSC 120 or its equivalent, or permission of the instructor.

description: Research seminar on a core or emerging topic in music history or musicology. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 credits if different topics are covered.
